section-block.rac_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Diana Murray and illustrated by Bryan Collier
section-block.rac_book_summary: There are so many shapes to find in the city! Learn about squares, rectangles, triangles, and other shapes on this bird’s-eye (and child’s-eye!) tour of a city. What shapes can you find where you live?

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce shapes. As you show a circle, triangle, and square, name each shape and briefly explain its features. A triangle has three straight sides and three corners.
It has four sides, all the same size.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read City Shapes written by Diana Murray and illustrated by Bryan Collier.
Lala loves all sorts of books, but Lala especially loves informational texts like this one. There are so many shapes to see!
There is a question that I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is something in the city that looks like a shape?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at all of the buildings! A city is a place with a lot of tall buildings, where many people live. We are going to read about shapes we can find in a city.
I see squares! What shape are the windows in this picture?
There are more squares in this picture! How many yellow squares do you see? Let’s count only the yellow squares. (MB)
How many sides do these triangles have? Where do you see triangles in the picture?
A circle is a special shape because it is one curved line. Where do you see a circle?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is something in the city that looks like a shape?
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A window looks like a square.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about finding shapes in everyday objects as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What shape are the boats’ sails?
A boat sail is shaped like a tr___ (triangle).
A boat sail is shaped like a triangle.
What other objects are shaped like squares?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Although many children begin to learn shapes before preschool, they may not realize that they already find shapes every day. Recognizing shapes in familiar contexts helps provide children with a foundational understanding of conceptual geometry and prepares them to draw and use shapes themselves.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Classify and Organize

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When we classify and organize, we group objects together that are alike. We can classify and organize based on attributes like color, shape, size, sound—any feature that objects, ideas, people, or even words might have in common. Informational texts like this one provide many opportunities to classify and organize!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will revisit City Shapes. We will practice classifying and organizing the shapes we see.
When Clifford reads, he thinks about how to classify and organize information. Clifford thinks about what is the same in the words and pictures.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The words kind and find have the same ending sound! They rhyme. Did you notice that the words in this book are organized so that the lines rhyme? What other words rhyme with kind? (MB)
There are so many rectangles on this page! Where do you see a rectangle?
Some of these shapes are smaller, or turned a different way. Are they still rectangles? How can you tell? (MB)
There are flags from many countries on this page! What shape are these flags?
Let’s group them by color. First let’s count the flags that have the color red in them. Now, let’s count the flags that don’t have red. (MB)
Should we group the flags in our classroom with the flags that have red or the flags that don’t have red?
Look at the tops of the buildings. What shapes do you see? I see rectangles and squares. Let’s look at some of the shapes and decide whether it belongs in the square group or the rectangle group
How should we group this shape? Is it a rectangle or a square?

section.rac_body-text: Give children colored pencils, paper, and other art supplies. Ask them to imagine they are taking a trip to a city. Invite them to draw what they picture, encouraging them to use the shapes in the book to create streets, buildings, and people.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about which shapes they see where they live.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Symbolic thinking, or using one thing to stand for something else, is an important skill for preschoolers. Thinking symbolically is what allows us to represent people with dolls and real-world scenes with drawings. As you read, remind children that the drawings in City Shapes represent things that exist in real life. (Bredekamp, 2007)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that a square is flat. Hold up a connecting cube, and show that when a square is not flat, it is called a cube or a box. Discuss other familiar three-dimensional shapes.
Play a game of “Simon Says” using shapes. “Simon” should suggest children draw familiar shapes, or create shapes using their fingers or arms.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread City Shapes written by Diana Murray and illustrated by Bryan Collier.
Lala loves searching for shapes in the pictures.
Shapes are everywhere! As we read today, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Where do the girl and the pigeon find shapes in the city?

section.rac_body-text: Facilitate back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: There are lots of packages on the cart! The sides look like they are squares. But are these flat shapes? What shapes are they?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to understand that these are boxes, not just squares.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see lots of triangles!
Flags can be triangles too. Let’s group these flags. First, let’s count the flags that are pointing down. Now, let’s count the ones that are pointing up. (MB)
Even though the flags are pointing in different directions, are they all triangles? How can you tell?
There are so many circles on this page! Where do you see a circle?
These bubbles are drawn like circles. When you blow a bubble is it a flat shape? What do you call a round shape that is not flat?
section.rac_body-text: Guide children to understand that bubbles are spheres, or balls, not flat circles.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What shapes do you see on these pages? Can you find a rectangle? What about a square? Are there any circles? Where did you look to find those shapes?
Let’s talk about the guiding question. Where do the girl and the pigeon find shapes in the city?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about shapes found in the classroom.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do the girl and the pigeon look at buildings?
They look at buildings to find sh____ (shapes).
They look at buildings to find shapes.
Where can you look to find shapes in our classroom?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children often learn new words incidentally, through conversations, books, and listening to others. Shape names, however, are used relatively infrequently and need to be taught explicitly. Increase children’s exposure to these words by frequently pointing out shapes in context and naming them.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Revisit and discuss the shapes children have learned about and where in the city they can be found. Ask, How is the city in the book different from where you live?
Play a game of “I Spy” using shapes. For example: I spy a circle outside. Guide children to look for circles outside and guess which one you are looking at.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Our Neighborhood. It is an informational poster that shows important places in a town.
Our Neighborhood and City Shapes both focus on places where people live. Let’s look for connections between the two as we read.
What is it like where we live?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Where We Live
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Geometry: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and talk about shapes in the picture.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A map is a picture of a place that shows where important things are, like streets and buildings. Do you see any circles on this map?
Why does the library have a book on it? What can you do there? Have you ever been to a library?
What shape is the book? What shapes are the windows? (MB)
Let’s find the post office. In City Shapes, we saw someone delivering packages in boxes! There are post offices in towns and in cities.
Is there a post office in your neighborhood? Where do you go to send mail?
What shape are the bakery shelves? What shape is its door? The door is standing up, and the shelves are on their sides. Are they all still rectangles? (MB)
What shapes do you see on the playground? Where do you go to play in your neighborhood? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Bring children on a shape walk through your neighborhood. Point out the shapes you see as you walk. Encourage children to point out any shapes they see, too. If you are not able to go outside, take a shape walk around your school or classroom.
Provide a writing prompt about children’s neighborhoods. Give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For preschoolers, geography is about more than recognizing the buildings and natural features they see. When young children build awareness of the world around them, they start to develop a sense of connectedness to the place where they live. This connectedness, commonly called sense of place, is crucial for social-emotional health.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: OUR COMMUNITY | WEEK 2: Where We Live

section-block.rac_body-text: Tape a large piece of paper or a poster to the wall, and gather drawing tools. Work with children to create a class drawing of a neighborhood using shapes. Prepare children to draw by tracing each shape in the air as you name it: square; rectangle; circle; triangle. Help children label the places in the neighborhood.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read City Shapes one last time this week.
Lala wonders if this book tells a story or teaches information. Do you remember?
We have learned about many different shapes and important places in a neighborhood. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can we use shapes to draw the things we see in our neighborhood?

section.rac_body-text: As you read the book and discuss the prompts, have children add to the class drawing. Use Equity Sticks to make sure that all children participate.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Buildings in the city are tall! Do these look like skyscrapers?
What buildings are in your neighborhood? What shape are they? Who can come up and draw a rectangle to be a building?
I see some windows in this building. What shape are they? Who can draw some square windows for our building?
Are there taxis in your neighborhood? What about cars or bicycles? What shape are the wheels on these vehicles?
We can use rectangles to draw cars. Who wants to add circles for wheels?

I see trees in this picture! Are there trees in your neighborhood? Let’s group some trees together in our picture! Who can draw tall rectangle trees on this side? Who can draw short triangle trees on this side?
A star is a shape with five points. Do you see stars in your neighborhood at night? Who can draw some stars in the sky?
How can we use shapes to draw the things we see in our neighborhood?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: We can use rectangles to draw buildings.
We can use squares to draw windows.
We can use circles to draw wheels.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about neighborhood shapes and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What shape can we use to draw windows?
We can use squares to draw w____ (windows).
We can use squares to draw windows.
What else can we use shapes to draw?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Creating art is an important part of young children’s development. Drawing teaches fine motor skills, math skills like size and shapes, and cognitive skills like planning and cause and effect. Free expression is particularly important as a healthy outlet. Encourage children to be creative as they draw their neighborhood shapes.
